Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The family requires money for daily living expenses, and the mother needs to provide it
Situation2: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Story: I sit in the cramped break room, my lunch untouched, eyes scanning the latest pharmacy newsletter. New drugs, new protocols—so much to keep up with. My phone buzzes with a message from my husband: “We’re short on groceries again. Can you pick up extra shifts this week?” My heart sinks. I know the kids need new shoes, and the bills are piling up. I want to be the mother who provides, who keeps the fridge full and the lights on. But as a pharmacist, I’m expected to stay sharp, to know every new medication, every side effect. If I don’t keep up, I risk falling behind, making mistakes, losing respect at work. My mind races—should I volunteer for overtime, sacrificing precious hours with my children, or should I spend my evenings studying, ensuring I’m the best pharmacist I can be? The weight of both worlds presses down on me, and I feel torn, unable to give either role what it truly deserves.
